intro: Chamaesciadium acaule, commonly known as the naked-stemmed bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its lack of a distinct stem, with leaves directly arising from the base. The plant produces small, bell-shaped blue or purple flowers that bloom in late summer. It thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as meadows and hillsides. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
